get off.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to leave a place, or to help someone to leave a place
get off.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: We’ll try and get off straight after lunch.
I’ll phone you as soon as I’ve got the children off to school.
get off.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to finish work and leave the place where you work at the end of the day
get off.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: I usually get off at six o’clock.
What time do you get off work?
get off.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to send a letter or package by post
get off.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: I’ll have to get this letter off by tonight.
I’ll get the forms off to you today.
get off.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to remove a piece of clothing
get off.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: Why don’t you get those wet clothes off?
get off.translation[0].definitions[4].de: if someone gets off, they are not punished for doing something wrong, or they receive only a small punishment
get off.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: In the end he got off because there wasn’t enough evidence against him.
The police felt he had got off very lightly.
If you’re lucky, you’ll get off with a fine.
get off.translation[0].definitions[5].de: to help someone avoid being punished for a crime
get off.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: Her lawyers were confident that they could get her off.
get off.translation[0].definitions[6].de: to go to sleep, or to help a child go to sleep
get off.translation[0].definitions[6].ex: I went to bed but couldn’t get off to sleep.
It took us ages to get the baby off.
get off.translation[0].definitions[7].de: to start in a particular way
get off.translation[0].definitions[7].ex: The day had got off to a bad start.
get off.translation[0].definitions[8].de: to stop talking about a subject
get off.translation[0].definitions[8].ex: Can we get off the subject of death, please?
get off.translation[0].definitions[9].de: used to tell someone to stop touching something or someone
get off.translation[0].definitions[9].ex: Get off those cakes, or there’ll be trouble.
get off.translation[0].definitions[10].d: to tell someone that they are asking you for too much or are behaving in a way you will not accept
get off.translation[0].definitions[10].e: He wanted £50, but I told him where to get off.
get off.translation[0].definitions[11].d: used to tell someone that they should stop being lazy and start doing something useful
